messages.content:
based on everything you know about me what pros and cons of this contract are there and what might i take offense to. should i sign it, why or why not? I feel like it's a lot of legalese and i'm not sure what to pay attention to[[[ 
MASTER SERVICES AGREEMENT

 

This Master Services Agreement (Hereinafter “Agreement”) is made and entered at Mumbai on 10th April 2025 (The “Effective Date”)

 

By And Between

Text And Clicks (Hereinafter “TnCA” or “Client”) a company incorporated under the Companies Act 2013 and having its registered office at Office number 7, Engineer's Premises, Adjacent to Bombay Stock Exchange, Fort, Mumbai which includes it successors and permitted assigns

 

AND

 
_______________________________ (Hereinafter “Service Provider”), an independent consultant having their address at ______________________________________________, which includes their successors and permitted assigns.
 

The Client, the Service Provider are hereinafter referred to individually as a "Party" and collectively as the "Parties".

 

RECITALS

 

A. WHEREAS TnCA is an Ed-tech company and is engaged in the business of providing online learning materials with focus on entrepreneurship, employability, industry-relevant programs, experiential instruction, and outcome-based learning;
B. WHEREAS The Service Provider is in the business of providing learning support;
C. WHEREAS TnCA is willing to procure certain services more specifically defined in this Agreement;
D. WHEREAS The Service Provider has represented that it has experience and skill and is competent to provide consultancy, advisory and other related services to the Client;
 
NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the foregoing, the mutual promises and undertakings set forth below, and other good and valuable consideration exchanged by the parties, the receipt and sufficiency of which are acknowledged by the parties, the parties agree as follows:

 

1. Engagement of Service Provider and Description of the Services:
 
1.1. Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Client hereby engages Service Provider to provide Services, related tasks and activities, and any other services incidental thereto, as described in a Statement of Work (a “SOW”), that conforms, substantially, to the requirements set forth in Schedule A. Each SOW signed between the parties will be deemed to be part of and governed by the terms and conditions of this Agreement.  For the purposes of interpretation and enforcement of this Agreement, “Services” means, collectively, all of the services to be performed by Service Provider limited to those described in a SOW or any change order issued by Client as mutually agreed between Parties.  Service Provider shall not commence performing any Services set forth in a SOW until both parties have executed such SOW. If there are more than one SOW, they will be accordingly numbered.
 
(a) Service Provider acknowledges that time is of essence and all the Services must be performed and submitted as per the timelines in SOW, and shall be liable for delay in any Deliverable which is solely attributable to the Service Provider. For the purposes of interpretation and enforcement of this Agreement, “Deliverables” means, all and any work product, and other items, including but not limited to content, process/es, research work/s, newsletter/s, publication/s or data for the purpose of publication/s, graphic/s, video/s, question/s, notes, memoranda, summaries, curriculum, programs, reports, analyses, compilations, content, study/ies, images, drawings, software and programs, pdf document/s, recorded session/s, assessment/s, flash card/s, concepts, project/s or assignments, video, audio files, photographs or the like, learning pedagogy, platform design features, technology including but not limited to code, architecture, databases and the like and any other documents like pitch, training, branding and the like, conceived or developed for or delivered to Client by the Service Provider under this Agreement or SOW.
 
(b) Service Provider shall perform the Services in accordance with the service levels and other standards set forth in the SOW or any other policy or code prescribed from time to time.
 
(c) Service Provider will deliver services and also submit reports as requested by Client from time to time.
 
(d) Any change in the scope of services, schedule/s, charges and terms of this Agreement must be submitted in writing and executed by both parties before any action is taken.
 
(e) Service Provider acknowledges that the scope of service requires specific skill, including ability to work effectively in a fast-paced dynamic business environment of the Client and agrees to appoint Key Personnel(s) as specified in the SOW to perform the Services. The Service Provider shall not remove or substitute the Key Personnel during the Agreement term and such substitution or change will entitle Client to terminate the Agreement on immediate basis without incurring liability except payment obligations for service performed till such date.
(f) Service Provider shall ensure that its Key Employee(s), employees or sub-contractor engaged in the provision of the Services will at all times during the term of this Agreement while at Client’s premises, or any other location under control of Client:
 
- Act diligently, ethically, soberly and honestly;
- Wear the Client’s identification badges while inside at Client’s premises;
- Not take or use any drug unless prescribed by a medical practitioner or lawfully available without prescription and used in accordance with directions;
- Comply with all occupational health or safety policies of the Client including, but not limited to, those relating to a smoke-free environment;
- Comply with all procedures, rules, regulations, and standards of conduct and lawful directions of Client in respect of use of its premises, equipment, business ethics or methodology, or contact with its staff or Client.
 
2. Acceptance and Rejection of Deliverables
 
Unless otherwise stated in the SOW all and any Services executed under this Agreement will have agreed Deliverable/s at various stages. Once Client approves and asks Service Provider to work on next stage, Service Provider will assume that acceptance criteria are met. Service Provider will require explicit approval at every stage and any changes thereafter will be considered as change requests and will be as recorded.
 
3. Fees and Expenses
 
3.1. For the services to be performed under this Agreement, Client agrees to pay Service Provider the fees as per the details mentioned in Schedule A/SOW subject to deductions or adjustments of service level credits or penalties as may be applicable. The fee is exclusive of GST at applicable rates.
 
3.2. No out-of-pocket expenses is payable unless preapproved by Client in writing.  Any fee payable is subject to acceptance of the services/Deliverable by the Client.
 
3.3. There shall be no payment liability of Client under this Agreement, except under any effective  SOW.
 
4. Payment terms & tax deduction at source:
 
4.1. The Service Provider shall raise GST compliant invoices (If the Service Provider has a GST License) as per payment schedule in Schedule A/applicable SOW for the Services performed and upon written acceptance of Deliverables by the Client. Unless otherwise agreed the payment will be made within 45 days from the date of receipt of invoice by the Client.
 
4.2. The Client shall pay the Service Provider as per Schedule A/applicable SOW. Any dispute on the invoice will be raised by the Client within 45 days from the date of receipt of invoice and Client reserves the right to withhold payment for disputed Services which shall be resolved between parties as per dispute resolution process set out in this Agreement.
 
4.3. Payments shall be subject to withholding taxes, as shall be applicable in accordance with applicable laws. In case any other tax, cess, duty or charge is imposed on the Service provided under this Agreement, it shall be borne by the Service Provider. In the event, Service Provider fails to pay GST (If the Service Provider has a GST License) or file returns to the concerned department; the Client shall issue a debit note on to the Service Provider to recover the amount or adjust it against future payments.
 
4.4. The Service Provider shall be treated as an independent contractor for the purpose of taxation, and the Service Provider shall be liable for payment of taxes accordingly, and for filing the requisite tax and information returns and agrees to defend the Client against any tax liability or claim that may arise from the delivery of Services under this Agreement or SOW.
 
5. Confidential and Proprietary Information of the Parties.
5.1. In connection with the performance of the Services (including all periods prior to the signing of this Agreement and during the tenure of this Agreement), Client has or may have disclosed, or will or may disclose, to Service Provider, certain confidential and/or proprietary information and materials for the performance of the Services. For the purposes of this Agreement confidential information shall mean and includes without limitation (i)any information that is provided in a documentary or electronic form or other physical embodiment by Client to the Service Provider;(ii) any information disclosed, either directly or indirectly, in writing or orally or by inspection of tangible objects including and without limitation to all secret information, content, data, documents, proposals, outlines, technical, conceptual or financial information, cost and pricing information, sales and marketing strategies, internal market analysis or forecasts, unannounced business relationships, information relating to research, products, software, services, development, inventions, processes, engineering, designs and patterns, processes and formulas, methods, techniques, computer software, programs or source code, customer list, addresses, telephone / fax / telex numbers, email addresses, investor information, research strategies, vendors, trade secrets and know-how, training, branding and the like disclosed by the Client to the Service Provider and any other information which is identified as being of a confidential or proprietary nature or which by its very nature shall be deemed confidential information of the Client;(iii)any other material bearing or incorporating any such information that is disclosed by Client to the Service Provider for the purpose of this Agreement or SOW, including confidential and proprietary trade secrets of the Client and/or all other information belonging or relating to Client that is not generally known; (hereinafter “Confidential Information”).
5.2. During the term of this Agreement and after termination or expiration of this Agreement for any reason the Service Provider:
(a) will not use Confidential Information for a purpose other than the performance of its obligations under this Agreement;
(b) will not disclose Confidential Information to a person except with the prior written consent of the Client or in accordance with permitted disclosures herein; and
(c) will make every effort to prevent the use or disclosure of Confidential Information.
5.3. Service Provider may disclose Confidential Information to any of its directors, other officers and/or employees (a "Recipient") to the extent that disclosure is necessary for the purposes of this Agreement and will ensure that a Recipient is made aware of and complies Service Provider obligations of confidentiality under this Agreement.
5.4. Above restrictions do not apply to information that prior to disclosure or post disclosure becomes, publicly known other than by Service Provider or Service Provider 's breach of this Agreement; or can be shown by Service Provider to Client’s reasonable satisfaction to have been known by Service Provider before disclosure by Client to the Service Provider.
5.5. Service Provider shall protect and maintain the confidentiality of the Confidential Information of Client using at least the same level of care (but no less than reasonable care) than what Service Provider uses to protect and maintain the confidentiality of its own Confidential Information.
5.6. Client owns, exclusively, all copyrights, trademarks, service marks, trade secrets, know-how and other intellectual property rights embodied or contained in, or constituting part of, Client’s Confidential Information.
5.7. Service Provider agrees that upon expiry or termination of this Agreement or upon request by Client during the term, Service Provider will return to the Client all drawings, blue prints, notes, memoranda, specifications, designs, devices, documents and any other material containing or disclosing any Confidential Information including all Deliverables in tangible or intangible form within 7 working days from the date of request or termination.
5.8. If during the term of this Agreement Service Provider discloses any information which is confidential in nature (“Service Provider’s Confidential Information”) the Client agrees to apply similar confidentiality obligations towards such Service Provider’s Confidential Information.
5.9. Any disclosure required by law is permitted subject only to the extent necessary, and prior and prompt notice to the Client by the Service Provider to afford the Client a reasonable period of time to seek or obtain an appropriate protective order if one is desired and obtainable.
5.10. Breach of confidentiality term shall be deemed as material breach and in addition to termination rights Client shall be entitled (in addition to the recovery of any damages which are ascertainable and an award of other appropriate relief) to obtain from a court of competent jurisdiction injunctive relief (without being required to post bond or other security) to prevent or restrain, or limit the effects of, such breach​
5.11. The obligations set forth in this Clause shall survive termination of this Agreement.
 
6. Representations and Warranties of the Parties
 

Service Provider represents and warrants that (a) it will supply the Services in a timely manner and in accordance with the specifications and service levels in Schedule A;(b) Service Provider or its employees, agents, representatives or sub-contractor are adequately experienced, trained, qualified and skilled for the purpose of carrying out the Services;(c) the supply of the Services/Deliverables will not infringe any intellectual property right of any third party or breach any duty of confidence owed to any third party; (d) the execution of this Agreement by it and the performance by it of its obligations and duties hereunder, do not and will not violate the terms of any agreement to which it is a party, or by which it is otherwise bound; and (e) it has all licenses, authorizations, consents, approvals and permits required by applicable law in order to perform its obligations under this Agreement and will continue to do so for the term of this Agreement.

 
7. Intellectual Property Rights and Ownership
 

7.1. Except for any confidential or proprietary materials which belong to third parties or in which Service Provider has a pre-existing intellectual property interest (“Existing Materials”) belong with the Service Provider, all other materials including but not limited to content, process/es, research work/s, newsletter/s, publication/s or data for the purpose of publication/s, graphic/s, video/s, question/s, notes, memoranda, summaries, curriculum, programs, reports, analyses, compilations, content, study/ies, images, drawings, software and programs, pdf document/s, recorded session/s, assessment/s, flash card/s, concepts, project/s or assignments, video, audio files, photograms or the like, learning pedagogy, platform design, technology or other materials made or conceived by Service Provider in the course of providing Services/Deliverable or resulting from Service Provider’s Services and any inventions, copyright, ideas or original works of authorship in whole or in part conceived or made by Service Provider, whether or not protectable by patent, trademark, copyright or other applicable law, which arise from or result from the Services/Deliverables, its  employees, its agents or its subcontractors, alone or jointly with Client employees or other persons, for Client hereunder (collectively, “Works”) shall belong exclusively to Client, whether or not fixed in a tangible medium of expression.  
Without limiting the foregoing, Service Provider agrees that all Works shall be deemed to be “works made for hire”.  Service Provider hereby irrevocably assigns and transfers such property, and all right, title and interests therein, including but not limited to patents, designs, trademarks, copyrights to Client and its successors and assigns on perpetual, worldwide, on a fully paid up and royalty free basis, against consideration received under this Agreement towards fee or incentive.  Service Provider grants Client all rights including, without limitation, its moral rights, in perpetuity and worldwide with respect to such Works on a fully paid up and royalty free basis.  Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, title to Works or other tangible work product produced by Service Provider, its employees, its agents or its subcontractors, alone or jointly with Client employees or other persons pursuant to this Agreement shall become the property of Client when produced.

Service Provider shall not incorporate any Existing Material, Service Provider content or technology or any third party materials or content (“Prohibited Materials”) into the Deliverables without the express prior permission of the Client, and if used or to the extent the Deliverables includes Prohibited Materials, Service Provider shall provide the Client with an irrevocable, non-exclusive, global, perpetual, sub-licensable, fully paid up, royalty free license to use, all such content shared in connection with the Deliverables strictly in conjunction with the Deliverables

7.2. The Client shall have unfettered rights to modify, improve, adapt, publish online or offline, distribute, create derivative works out of the Deliverable, including Service Provider’s Key personnel’s name or photographs, make copy thereof, broadcast, including exploitation for commercial purposes and Service Provider agrees that it and its personnel including third party shall not make any claims against said rights.
7.3. Service Provider shall not directly or indirectly use, lease, license, modify, create derivative works, disassemble Works created for the Client in any manner and this restriction is material and shall survive termination of this Agreement.
7.4. The obligations set forth in this Clause shall survive termination of this Agreement.
 
 
8. Indemnity and Limitation of Liability
8.1. Service Provider shall indemnify and hold harmless the Client, their affiliates, group entities, promoters, directors, officers, employers, agents and authorized representatives (“Indemnified Persons”) against any direct losses, costs or claims which the Indemnified Persons might incur/suffer directly as a result of the breach of this Agreement on part of the Service Provider.
8.2. Service Provider agrees to indemnify, hold harmless and protect and defend Indemnified Persons from and against any and all actions, causes of action, claims, demands, cost, liabilities, and expenses (including attorney’s fees) arising out of, or in connection with (i) the inaccuracy or untruthfulness of any representation, warranty or covenant made by Service Provider or use of Service/Deliverable by the Client under this Agreement; or (ii) from any loss, expense, damage or personal injury, death and any claim for payment of compensation, salary, retirement benefits, or any other fringe benefits asserted by an employee of Service Provider; or (iii) any claim that the Services performed or any Deliverables delivered or provided to Client by Service Provider under this Agreement constitute an infringement of any confidential information, trade secret, patent, copyright, trademark, trade name, or other legal right of any third party; or (iv) loss due delay in the performance of Services; (vi) any claims arising due to use of Prohibited Materials in the Services/Deliverable which constitutes an infringement of any confidential information, trade secret, patent, copyright, trademark, trade name, or other legal right of any third party rights; and (vii) any claims arising from the violation of any laws by the Service Provider.
8.3. If any Indemnified Persons are entitled to indemnification hereunder, Indemnified Persons shall give notice to the Service Provider of the losses, claim, demands cost, liabilities, expenses and of the commencement of any proceeding against the Indemnifying Persons or third party claims with respect to which such Indemnified Persons seeks indemnification pursuant hereto, provided, however, that any delay to so notify the Service Provider shall not relieve it from any obligation or liability under this Clause. The Service Provider shall forthwith within a period of 15 (Fifteen) days on receipt of such notice, reimburse to the Indemnified Party an amount equal to all losses, claim, demands cost, liabilities, expenses as set out in the notice issued by the Indemnified Persons.
For the avoidance of doubt, it is clarified that any amount payable to Indemnified Persons shall be on an ‘after tax basis’ and shall be grossed up, if and to the extent any tax is required to be paid in relation to such amount.

8.4. EXCEPT FOR BREACHES OF INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS, CONFIDENTIALITY OBLIGATIONS, NEGLIGENCE OR CLAIMS THAT CANNOT BE LIMITED UNDER LAW NEITHER PARTY WILL BE LIABLE TO THE OTHER PARTY FOR ANY INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, CONSEQUENTIAL, SPECIAL, OR EXEMPLARY DAMAGES ARISING OUT OF OR RELATED TO THIS AGREEMENT, EVEN IF THE OTHER PARTY HAS BEEN ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGES AND REGARDLESS OF WHETHER SUCH LIABILITY SOUNDS IN CONTRACT, TORT, STRICT LIABILITY, WARRANTY, OR OTHERWISE.
9. Term, Termination and Consequences of Termination
9.1. This Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date of this Agreement, and shall be valid for a term of 1 year from the date of this Agreement unless terminated prior as per terms below. The Agreement may be renewed or extended by mutual agreement between Parties.
9.2. Except as provided in Clause 9.3, the Service Provider shall not be entitled to terminate the Agreement until the services under this Agreement or SOW, agreed to be delivered as per the specification in Schedule A is completed except for non-payment of fee by Client which is overdue for more than 60 days and is not subject to any fee dispute.
9.3. Notwithstanding the aforesaid, the Service Provider may terminate the Agreement for reason by giving two [2] month’s written notice to the Client. Service Provider shall ensure diligence in the performance of Services during such termination period.
9.4. Client is entitled to terminate this Agreement for convenience by a fifteen (15) days prior written notice of termination without incurring any liability except for Services performed by the Service Provider and accepted by the Client.
9.5. Client may terminate this Agreement, in whole or in part, if Service Provider breaches any of its material duties or obligations under this Agreement or SOW and fails to comply with any prescribed code of conduct and fails to cure such breach within thirty (30) days after receipt of notice.
9.6. Client reserves the right to terminate the present engagement summarily without any prior notice period, if it has reasonable ground to believe that Service Provider or any one acting for it is guilty of misconduct or negligence, or have committed any fraud or material breach of agreement or caused any loss to the Client.
9.7. Upon termination or Client request, the Service Provider shall return all material containing Confidential Information, Services/Deliverables (whether completed or part performed) including but not limited to all other properties of the Client conceived, created, designed or developed, within seven (7) days from the date of the termination of this Agreement.
9.8. Each party’s further rights and obligations will cease immediately on expiry or termination except that those Clauses which are intended to survive for the interpretation or enforcement of this Agreement, will survive expiry or termination of this Agreement and will continue in full force and effect.
9.9. Upon expiration or termination of this Agreement for any reason, Service Provider will provide all reasonable assistance requested by Client to assure a smooth transition of the Services to an alternative service provider or to in-source the Service back to the Client at no additional cost.
9.10. Non-Compete - Service provider or its affiliates under no circumstances, directly or indirectly engage with the clients of the client and all other connections for the term of the entire agreement and for a period of 2 years after the termination of the agreement. In case of breach of the non-compete clause, the service provider will immediately be liable to pay a sum INR 5 lakhs as penalty.
10. Work Restriction
Service Provider acknowledges that any use/abuse/misuse whatsoever of the Confidential Information and/or the Deliverable or Work by the Service Provider in contravention of this Agreement during the term or after the termination shall be unauthorized and Client shall be authorized to initiate appropriate legal action against Service Provider including claiming indemnification for loss or damages arising therefrom.

11. General Terms
11.1. Service Provider will maintain the insurance coverage in accordance with all federal, state and local requirements.
11.2. Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed as to create the relationship of employer-employee, partners, collaborators, joint-venture or principal-agent between the parties hereto. The parties shall be independent contractors and neither party shall bind the other by its acts, deeds or omissions, other than to the extent set out in this Agreement.
 
11.3. Service Provider will maintain complete and accurate records of all the transactions contemplated under this Agreement. Service Provider agrees to provide the Client with documentation and other information as may be reasonably requested by the Client to verify accuracy and compliance with the provisions of this Agreement.
 
11.4. Neither party shall be liable for any failure or delay in fulfilling the terms of this Agreement due to fire, strike, war, civil unrest, terrorist action, government regulations, acts of Nature or other causes which are unavoidable in nature and beyond the reasonable control of the party claiming force majeure. The time for performance of such terms shall be suspended for the duration of such force majeure up to one month, upon which either party may elect to terminate this Agreement or any purchase order hereunder on ten days prior written notice provided such conditions continue to exist. This provision shall not be construed as relieving either party from its obligation to pay any sum due to the other party for Services accepted.
 
11.5. This Agreement including Schedule constitutes the entire Agreement between the parties on its subject and overrides all previous arrangements and agreements, either oral or written, between the parties hereto. Any amendments may be made in writing only with the signature of both parties. In the event of any conflict between the terms of the Agreement and terms of SOW in Schedule A which are specifically agreed therein shall be given precedence over terms of this Agreement
 
11.6. Any amendments to this Agreement shall only be valid if set out in writing (excluding email) and signed by both parties.
 
11.7. Any disputes arising between the Parties shall be resolved by mutual reconciliation within 30 days of the occurrence or notice of the dispute by one Party to the other. In the absence of any resolution, Parties may exercise their legal remedies as may be available herein.
 
If any Dispute cannot be resolved by the Parties, the Dispute shall be resolved through binding arbitration under the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 (“Arbitration Act”) and applicable amendments by reference to a sole arbitrator to be mutually appointed by the Parties. In case of failure of the Parties to agree to the identity of the sole arbitrator within thirty (30) days from the date of reference of the Dispute for arbitration, the sole arbitrator shall be appointed in accordance with the provisions of the Arbitration Act. The place of arbitration shall be Mumbai and any award whether interim or final, shall be made, and shall be deemed for all purposes between the Parties to be made, in Mumbai. The arbitral procedure shall be conducted in the English language and any award or awards shall be rendered in English. The procedural law of the arbitration shall be Indian law. Either Party shall bear their respective cost of Arbitration.

Notwithstanding the above, either Party may bring proceedings before courts in Mumbai for the purpose of seeking an injunction, order or other interim relief under applicable laws.

11.8. The headings utilized in this Agreement are for convenience only and are not to be construed in any way as additions or limitations of the covenants and agreements contained in this Agreement.
 
11.9. No forbearance or tolerance on the part of the Client of any breach of this Agreement by the Service Provider shall constitute waiver of the requirements of this Agreement by the Client. The Service Provider acknowledges that the Client shall continue to be entitled to enforce the terms of this Agreement nevertheless.
 
11.10. This Agreement shall be governed and construed in accordance with the laws of the India and place of breach is not relevant in this matter. In the event of any dispute parties submit to the exclusive jurisdiction of courts of Mumbai.
 
11.11. All notices under this Agreement shall be in writing, sent by facsimile, electronically (including email of the designated contact) or first-class registered post or recorded delivery post to the Party being served at its registered office or at such other address of which such Party shall have given notice as aforesaid, and marked for the attention of that Party’s signatory of this Agreement.  The date of service shall be deemed to be the day following the day on which the notice was transmitted or posted as the case may be.
 
11.12. This Agreement along with Schedule is a contract for professional services, and therefore, the Service Provider shall not be entitled to assign his responsibilities, obligations or liabilities under this Agreement.
 
11.13. A copy of this Agreement is signed by both the parties hereunder and acknowledged as acceptance of the above terms and conditions.
 

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties have hereto executed this Agreement on the day and date herein below written.

 

For and on behalf of ​​    For and on behalf of

Text and Clicks​

 

Signed by  ​   Signed by  

Designation:                                                                        Designation:

Date:​   Date:

Witness No.1​​​​​​   Witness No.2

Name:​​​​​​​   Name:

Designation:​​​​​​   Designation

 
APPENDIX A

STATEMENT OF WORK NO.  1

 

This Statement of Work (“SoW”) dated _______________ is incorporated as an attachment to the Master Service Agreement between TnCA Private Limited (hereinafter “TnCA”) and _______________ (“Service Provider”) dated the ____________________ (the "Master Agreement").
 

1. Services to be provided
 
a) Overview & Deliverables
 
The scope of the Service Provider is to review eLearning content for the course Environment, Social and Governance. The scope includes but is not limited to the following:
 
1) Review the base content for each module (concept notes, case studies, assessments, reading materials, etc.) for accuracy, relevance, and adherence to the outlined learning outcomes.
2) Provide feedback as comments on the Word documents in which the base content is received.
3) Partake in periodic calls with the vendor SME for discussions around feedback if/when required.
4) Sign-off on all content fixes.
5) Facilitation of _________ face to face /virtual sessions by Faculty ______________
 
2. Company Obligations
 
Company to provide signoffs for all deliverables after due internal review-feedback-fixes cycle.
 
 
3. Acceptance
 
Feedback for delivered files to be reviewed and shared with TnCA within 7 days. Files to be shared via Microsoft OneDrive on a location shared by TnCA. Once sign-off is completed, an email will be generated confirming the same to the Service Provider, after which they can send the relevant invoice for payment.
 
 
4. Charges
 
a) Total Payment Due for 16 sessions is __________ per hour for a total of ___________ inclusive of all taxes
 
b) Payment will be cleared within 30 days of invoicing. This is subject to change if during validation, durations of course or scope changes.
c) All Services are of essence to adhere to the timelines and the Service Provider is not entitled to terminate this SOW until the Services to be performed hereunder is complete.
d) In the case of the Service Providers' delay with the work handover within the deadline pursuant hereto, TnCA shall charge a contractual penalty of 2.5% of the agreed upon project cost.
 
 
 

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties have hereto executed this Statement of Work on the day and date herein below written.

 

For and on behalf of ​​​For and on behalf of

Text and Clicks​​

 

Signed by  ​         ​Signed by  

Designation:                                                                              ​Designation:  

Date:  ​          ​Date:  

 ]]]

Got you, Bilal. Short answer first:

**TL;DR — Don’t sign this as-is.** It’s very client-leaning on IP, liability, non-compete, payments, and jurisdiction. If you can’t get key redlines (below), I’d walk.

---

## Pros (a few)
- Mutual confidentiality (with an option for you to designate your own confidential info).
- Independent-contractor status stated.
- Consequential damages excluded (but see “no cap” under cons).
- Force-majeure exists (though short).

## Big cons / red flags (what to pay attention to)
1. **IP grab (7.1–7.4 + 1.1(a)):**  
   “Works made for hire,” full assignment *and* waiver of moral rights, **covering basically everything** (curriculum, pedagogy, tech, code, architecture, databases, recorded sessions, etc.). You’re also barred from reusing “Works” (7.3). This conflicts with your model of reusable frameworks/templates and your Baraka/Come-Alive/Parliaments IP.
2. **Use of your name & image (7.2):**  
   “Unfettered rights” to use your name/photos and to commercially exploit derivatives. Zero consent/approval rights.
3. **Non-compete (9.10):**  
   Blanket ban on engaging with *their clients* during the term + **2 years after**, with a fixed INR 5,00,000 penalty. (Post-term non-competes are often challengeable in India, but you don’t want to rely on that; the penalty is still a risk.)
4. **Indemnity is one-way and huge (8.1–8.3):**  
   You indemnify for almost everything (incl. **delays** and 3P IP claims), reimburse within 15 days, and “after-tax” gross-up. No reciprocal indemnity for their materials/instructions.
5. **No liability cap:**  
   Consequential damages are excluded, but there’s **no cap on direct damages** or on your indemnity. That’s untenable.
6. **Termination asymmetry (9.2–9.6):**  
   They can terminate for convenience with 15 days. You **can’t** terminate until completion (except narrow cases) and elsewhere it says “2 months for reason.” That’s internally inconsistent and unfavorable.
7. **Payment & acceptance leverage (3–4 & SoW 3–4):**  
   MSA says Net-45; SoW says Net-30 (SoW may prevail, but it’s inconsistent). Acceptance is at each stage and can stall your invoicing; penalties of **2.5%** of project cost for delay (SoW 4.d) + general “time is of the essence” liability.
8. **Jurisdiction & seat:**  
   **Indian law, Mumbai seat/arbitration, Mumbai courts for interim relief.** Expensive for you to contest and enforce.
9. **“Prohibited Materials” (7.1):**  
   You can’t include your standard libraries, templates or third-party content without prior permission, and if you do, they still get a perpetual license tied to the deliverable.
10. **Operational overreach (1.6 & site rules):**  
    No substitution of “Key Personnel” without their right to terminate; on-premise rules (badges, etc.) even if you’re remote.
11. **Taxes:**  
    Withholding/TDS risk, GST references, debit notes if you “fail to file,” and no clear DTAA treatment or gross-up protection for non-resident status.

## What you might take offense to (tone & posture)
- “Unfettered rights” to your work **and** to your name/photo (7.2).  
- The scope of “Deliverables” naming **your pedagogy, tech, and code** as theirs.  
- A **blanket two-year non-compete** + preset monetary penalty.  
- One-way indemnity and “reimburse in 15 days” with gross-up.  
- “Service Provider shall not… create derivative works” of what *you* made (7.3).  
- Immediate termination if you change Key Personnel (1.6(e)).  
- Mumbai-only law, courts, and arbitration for a global, remote engagement.

---

## Minimum redlines to ask for (prioritize these)
1. **IP / Background IP carve-outs**  
   - Define **Background IP** / **Existing Materials** broadly (methods, frameworks, templates, code, tools, know-how).  
   - Deliverables = **course-specific content** specified in the SoW (not platform design, generic pedagogy, code, databases).  
   - Replace “work made for hire + assignment” with: **non-exclusive, perpetual, worldwide license** to Client **for the Deliverables only**, with no right for Client to claim ownership of your Background IP.  
   - Add **Residuals clause** (you can use general know-how learned).  
   - Remove/limit 7.3 so you can reuse your own materials in other contexts.
2. **Name & image (7.2):**  
   Change to **marketing use only with your prior written consent**, non-disparaging, no implication of endorsement.
3. **Non-compete (9.10):**  
   Strike it. If they insist, convert to **non-solicit** of *named* Client accounts you directly work with, **12 months max**, no liquidated damages (or a modest, reasonable cap).
4. **Indemnity & liability:**  
   - Limit your indemnity to **(a)** third-party IP infringement of Deliverables (excluding Client-provided materials/instructions), and **(b)** your **gross negligence or willful misconduct**.  
   - Add **Client indemnity** for Client materials/instructions.  
   - **Cap all liability** (including indemnity) at **fees paid under the applicable SoW** (or 12-month fees).  
   - Remove “after-tax gross-up” and the 15-day reimbursement clock.
5. **Termination & convenience:**  
   - Mutual **30-day convenience termination**; if Client terminates, they pay for work done **+ non-cancellable committed costs**.  
   - Clean up 9.2 vs 9.3 conflict; allow you to terminate for non-payment (≥15–30 days overdue), material scope change, or material breach (with cure).
6. **Acceptance & payments:**  
   - **Deemed acceptance**: X business days after delivery if no written, specific rejection.  
   - **Milestones** with **Net-15/30** and **late-fee/interest**.  
   - Remove/limit the **2.5% penalty**; if they insist, apply only after a cure period and **cap total penalties** (e.g., 10% of SoW fees).
7. **Jurisdiction / seat:**  
   - Move to a neutral forum (e.g., **SIAC in Singapore** / **ICC in Paris**; remote hearings). If they won’t, at least allow remote proceedings and split venue/seat (neutral seat, virtual hearings).
8. **Taxes:**  
   - State fees are **exclusive of taxes**; Client will **provide TDS certificates** promptly; apply **DTAA** if you’re non-resident; no GST obligations if you don’t have an Indian GST registration. No debit notes for taxes that don’t apply to you.
9. **Personnel & subcontracting:**  
   - Allow substitution with **equivalently qualified** personnel on notice; reasonable consent not to be unreasonably withheld.  
   - Clarify you may use **specialist subcontractors**; you remain responsible.
10. **Third-party/FOSS & your templates:**  
    - Permit inclusion under their standard licenses; Client accepts those license terms.
11. **Publicity (mutual):**  
    - You can list Client name/logo as a portfolio item **with consent**; they can do likewise.
12. **Remote-first ops:**  
    - Remove on-premise badge rules unless you’re actually onsite.

---

## Should you sign?
- **As-is: No.** It jeopardizes your reusable IP, restricts your future work, and exposes you to uncapped risk in a foreign venue.  
- **Signable if they accept the core edits** (IP carve-out + license, liability cap, kill/soften non-compete, fair termination, clear acceptance/payments, neutral/remote dispute forum). If they only tweak cosmetics, it’s still a no.

---

## Quick redline snippets (drop-in language)
- **Background IP:**  
  “*‘Background IP’ means any methods, methodologies, frameworks, templates, tools, software (including source code), data models, know-how, inventions, and other materials developed or owned by Service Provider independently of this Agreement or outside the scope of a SoW, together with any improvements thereto.*”
- **License instead of assignment:**  
  “*Service Provider retains all right, title and interest in Background IP. For Deliverables created specifically for Client under an applicable SoW, Service Provider grants Client a perpetual, worldwide, non-exclusive, royalty-free license to use, reproduce, display, distribute, and create derivative works of such Deliverables solely for Client’s internal and external program needs. No assignment of Background IP is made or implied.*”
- **Residuals:**  
  “*Nothing restricts Service Provider’s use of ideas, know-how, and techniques retained in unaided memory.*”
- **Liability cap:**  
  “*Each party’s aggregate liability arising out of or related to a SoW shall not exceed the fees paid or payable under that SoW. Excludes liability that cannot be limited by law.*”
- **Indemnity (narrow):**  
  “*Service Provider indemnifies Client against third-party claims alleging Deliverables infringe IP, excluding claims arising from Client materials/instructions or combinations not supplied by Service Provider. Client indemnifies Service Provider for claims arising from Client materials/instructions.*”
- **Non-solicit (if needed):**  
  “*For 12 months post-engagement, Service Provider will not knowingly solicit paid work from the specific Client accounts listed in the SoW to which Service Provider was introduced by Client, excluding (i) inbound requests, (ii) pre-existing relationships, and (iii) general market outreach not targeted at such accounts.*”
- **Deemed acceptance:**  
  “*Deliverables are deemed accepted if Client does not provide written, specific rejection within 7 business days of delivery.*”
- **Payments:**  
  “*Milestone invoices Net-30; interest on late payments at 1.0% per month (or max lawful). Client shall not withhold undisputed amounts.*”
- **Disputes:**  
  “*Any disputes shall be finally resolved by arbitration seated in Singapore under SIAC Rules, conducted remotely in English.*”

---

Perfect — thanks, Bilal. Here’s a quick map in **one-sentence each** for the “other issues” besides IP, so you know what they want vs. what you should ask for:  

- **IP ownership:** They want *everything you produce, including methods/frameworks, forever.* → You should ask for *they own the specific deliverables, you retain your background IP and give them a broad license.*  
- **Non-compete:** They want *to block you from working with any of their clients for 2 years + fine.* → You should ask for *no non-compete, at most a short non-solicit of named accounts.*  
- **Indemnity:** They want *you to cover them for almost anything.* → You should ask for *mutual indemnity, limited to IP infringement and gross negligence.*  
- **Liability:** They want *unlimited direct liability.* → You should ask for *liability capped at fees paid under each SoW.*  
- **Payment/acceptance:** They want *net-45, acceptance only when they sign off, and penalties for your delay.* → You should ask for *net-30, deemed acceptance after 7 days, capped penalties.*  
- **Termination:** They want *to terminate on 15 days’ notice, you basically can’t.* → You should ask for *mutual 30-day termination for convenience.*  
- **Jurisdiction:** They want *Mumbai only.* → You can accept, but ask for *virtual hearings/arbitration so it’s not a burden.*  

---

### Draft Email (friendly, minimal-maximal changes)

Subject: A few clarifications on the services agreement  

Hi [Name],  

Thanks for sharing the Master Services Agreement — I really appreciate how thorough it is. I get the sense it’s a standard template you use across consultants, and I’d love to align it with how I normally work so that it’s practical for both of us.  

There are just a few areas I’d like to clarify or tweak:  

1. **Intellectual Property:** Since I bring a lot of existing methods and frameworks into my work, I’d like to keep ownership of my “background IP” (my tools, approaches, templates, etc.). Of course, you’d own the specific deliverables I create for you, and I’d grant you a broad, perpetual license to use them however you need. That way you get full rights to what you pay for, and I can continue improving my practice.  

2. **Non-compete:** The current wording blocks me from working with your clients for two years, which is quite restrictive. I’d suggest instead a short, limited non-solicit of named accounts I’m introduced to solely through this project.  

3. **Indemnity & Liability:** I’d like to make indemnities mutual and focused on things that really matter (IP infringement or gross negligence), and to cap liability at the fees paid under the SoW. That way neither of us takes on unlimited exposure.  

4. **Payment & Acceptance:** Could we set payments to Net-30, with a clear review window (e.g. deemed acceptance if no comments within 7 days)? That keeps cash flow predictable while still giving you a fair chance to review.  

5. **Termination:** It would feel more balanced if either party could terminate on 30 days’ notice, with payment for work completed.  

Everything else I’m fine with, including Mumbai jurisdiction — I’d just appreciate if hearings can be conducted virtually to save costs and time.  

I’ve attached a short rider that covers these points clearly, so we don’t have to edit your whole document line-by-line. Let me know if that works for you — I imagine most of these are standard adjustments for independent consultants.  

Looking forward to working together,  
Bilal

This “Vendor Registration Form” looks much less risky than the MSA — it’s basically an **administrative document** so they can put you in their payment system.  

Here’s how I’d break it down for you:  

---

### What it is
- Standard onboarding form: collects **contact info, tax IDs, and bank details** so they can pay you via NEFT/RTGS.  
- Includes a self-certification that your info is correct and that you’ll comply with their code of conduct (likely standard corporate ethics).  

### Pros
- Streamlines payments — avoids “lost invoices.”  
- No transfer of rights or restrictions beyond basic compliance.  
- Straightforward: just fill and attach PAN/GST/etc.  

### Cons / Watch-outs
- **Tax IDs:** If you don’t have certain numbers (TIN, VAT, CST, Service Tax — many are obsolete under GST), just leave blank or write “Not applicable.”  
- **MSME status:** If you’re registered as a Micro/Small/Medium Enterprise, you may get faster payment terms under Indian law — if not, leave blank.  
- **Bank info:** They’ll have your account details — only risk is normal data handling (make sure it’s their official email/portal).  
- **Declaration:** It references “William Penn Pvt Ltd Code of Conduct” — odd since the MSA is with “Text and Clicks.” Worth confirming it’s not just a copy-paste artifact.  

---

👉 Minimal response email you could send:

Also, I noticed the declaration references *William Penn Pvt Ltd* — should that be updated to *Text and Clicks*?  

Best,  
Bilal  

---

Good instinct, Bilal — before I draft that email, let me ask 5 clarifying questions so I know where you want to land on tone and content:  

1. **Tone** – Do you want the email to be collegial and light (“hey, thanks for sharing the draft, here are a few clarifications”), or more formal and lawyerly (“please see my redlines”)?  

2. **Negotiation posture** – Are you looking for *minimal edits you can live with* (like only IP carve-out and termination/payment fairness), or do you want to push for a more balanced contract (IP, liability cap, non-compete, indemnities, etc.)?  

3. **How much leverage you feel you have** – Do you think they’ll walk away if you push back too hard, or do you sense they need you and will accept most of your edits?  

4. **Confidentiality of your work** – For your frameworks and methods (Come Alive, Baraka, etc.), is the most important thing to you to *retain ownership* outright, or would you be okay with granting them a broad license if that keeps them comfortable?  

5. **Future reuse question (your “off time” concern)** – Would you like me to phrase it so that they explicitly acknowledge you *can reuse your general know-how and approaches anywhere else*, or do you prefer to keep that vague but still protected through “Background IP” language?  

Answer these, and then I’ll draft the tightest “minimal-maximal” change request email — something that gets them to agree to the essentials without turning into a full renegotiation.

Good question — and your instinct to pause on the “non-solicit” bit is right.  
Here’s what it actually means in **plain English**, and how it relates to your concern about building things in your off time 👇  

---

### 🧭 What “non-solicit” means
A **non-solicitation clause** is a softer, narrower version of a **non-compete**.  
Instead of banning you from working for others, it just says:

> “For X months after our contract ends, you won’t *actively approach* our clients or employees to offer them your own services.”

So:
- You **can** keep working with your own network, other clients, or totally new partners.  
- You **can** still accept work **if one of their clients contacts you first** (you just can’t *chase* them).  
- It usually applies only to **named accounts** or relationships you met *through them*.

---

### 🧱 Example
Let’s say Text & Clicks hires you to teach for a client like “ABC University.”

If your contract says a **non-solicit**, it means:
- You can’t reach out to ABC University and say “Hire me directly next time.”  
- But if ABC University later emails you independently and says “Hey Bilal, we loved your session — can you do a workshop for us?” you can **accept**, because *they* initiated it.

---

### ⚖️ Why it’s reasonable
This protects them from you cutting them out of their own deals — which is fair —  
but it doesn’t block you from creating or freelancing elsewhere, nor from building your own intellectual property.  

---

### 💡 How to keep yourself safe
Ask them to make it **explicit** that:
> “The non-solicit applies only to specific clients introduced to me through this engagement, and not to my general professional or creative work.”

That one line solves your “how will they know what I build in my off time?” worry —  
because your off-time projects, templates, or other clients stay **completely yours and outside their scope**.

---

without sounding defensive or legalistic. Would you like me to do that?

You’re right to pause and check this — let’s unpack it simply:  

### 💰 What the contract currently says about payment
In the **MSA**, the key payment clauses are:

- **4.1–4.2**: You invoice after deliverables are accepted in writing.  
  Client pays within **45 days** from receiving your invoice.  
- **SoW section 4(b)** says **payment will be cleared within 30 days** of invoicing.  
- They can withhold payment for *disputed* services or if acceptance hasn’t happened.  
- There’s **no late-payment interest** and no “automatic acceptance” clause.  

So, in practice:
- If they *delay reviewing* your deliverables, your invoice clock doesn’t even start yet.  
- And even once it starts, they technically have up to **45 days** to pay (depending which clause wins).  
- There’s no consequence if they pay late.

That means the “it seems ok” is only true **if they’re quick and organized** — but legally, it gives them a lot of slack and gives you none.

---

### 💡 Why your ask (Net-30 + 7-day automatic acceptance) is smart
You’re not asking for extra money — just:
1. **Net-30** → industry-standard; faster cashflow; aligns with SoW text.  
2. **7-day deemed acceptance** → stops deliverables from getting “stuck” in review limbo.  

Together they simply make sure:
- You get paid in ~5 weeks instead of 2–3 months.  
- Payment isn’t hostage to slow feedback.  

It’s a *practical safeguard*, not a power move — so it’s worth keeping in your email exactly as you wrote it.

---

ok, what if they don't review is there a max cap?

Excellent question — you’re thinking like someone who’s been burned before 👀  

Right now, in **their version**, there’s **no cap** on how long they can sit on your work.  
Here’s what happens under the current text:

> You can only invoice *after* they give written acceptance.

So if they simply *don’t review* your deliverables, the clock for payment **never starts**.  
That’s why your “auto-accept after 7 days” request is important — it *creates* a cap by default.  

---

### 🧭 How this works in practice
If you add that clause — “Deliverables are deemed accepted after 7 business days unless written feedback is provided” — it means:
- You deliver on Monday.  
- By the following Wednesday (7 business days later), silence = acceptance.  
- You can invoice immediately, and the 30-day payment window starts.  
- After 37 calendar days total, you must legally be paid.  

That’s the clean, enforceable cap.

---

### 🧱 Without it
If you leave it as-is, there’s **no upper limit** — they could delay review for weeks or months, and you’d have no formal trigger for payment.

---

### 🪄 Optional extra protection (if you want to be bulletproof)
You can add one soft line like:

> “If Client does not provide feedback within the 7-day review period, the Deliverables will be deemed accepted for invoicing purposes.”

That phrase — *for invoicing purposes* — keeps it friendly and non-legalistic, but it still gives you a firm clock.

---

✅ **Bottom line:**  
There’s *no cap* right now — your 7-day deemed acceptance **creates** it.  
Keep it in your email exactly as written. It’s one of the smallest, most protective tweaks you can make.
